pull.title: ModifyNewCoins saves database lookups
pull.body:
When processing a new transaction, in addition to spending the Coins of its txin's, it creates a new Coins for its outputs.  The existing ModifyCoins function will first make sure this Coins does not already exist.  It can not exist due to BIP 30, but because of that, the lookup can't be cached and always has to go to the database.  Since we are creating the Coins to match the new tx anyway, there is no point in checking if it exists first anyway.  However this should not be used for coinbase tx's in order to preserve the historical behavior of overwriting the two existing duplicate tx pairs.

In conjunction with #6931 this will help ConnectBlock be much more efficient with caching access to the database.

This still needs unit tests which exercise the new functionality.

events.message:
ModifyNewCoins saves database lookups

When processing a new transaction, in addition to spending the Coins of its txin's it creates a new Coins for its outputs.  The existing ModifyCoins function will first make sure this Coins does not already exist.  It can not exist due to BIP 30, but because of that the lookup can't be cached and always has to go to the database.  Since we are creating the coins to match the new tx anyway, there is no point in checking if they exist first anyway.  However this should not be used for coinbase tx's in order to preserve the historical behavior of overwriting the two existing duplicate tx pairs.

issue.title: Skip BIP 30 verification where not necessary
issue.body:
Since BIP 34 became active, it has been impossible to generate duplicate coinbases, and therefore not possible to generate any other duplicate transaction ID's.

This pull will allow us to skip BIP 30 verification if we know we are on a chain after the point BIP 34 was activated and there are no latent duplicate transaction chains.  
On mainnet there were 2 cases of duplicate coinbases, and in both cases the duplicate overwrote the original before there was an opportunity to spend it.
~~I have not actually verified that there are no duplicate coinbases on testnet3, and we need to verify that or turn off the skipping on testnet before merging this pull.~~ (EDIT: verified)

In conjunction with #6932 this will help ConnectBlock be much more efficient with caching access to the database.

events.body: ConceptACK, will review further and test.

issue.title: Summary of potential performance improvements
issue.body:
There are a lot of open PRs right now which will give significant performance improvements.
Below are some summary benchmarks on all of these PRs.  In each row, the relevant PR has been added to all the previous PR's, so the last row is the cumulative effect of all of them.
Please see notes below.

| PR | ConnectBlock time (ms) | Reduction in time from this PR | CreateNewBlock time (ms) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| baseline | 500 - 1500 |  |  |
| #6954(secp256k1) | 400 - 600 | 15%-65% |  |
| #6931(skip BIP30) #6932(modifyNewCoins) | 200 - 350 | 30%-40% | 3000 - 3500 |
| #6357(dynamic Priority) #6898(CreateNewBlock) | 200 - 350 | very small increase | 180 - 230 |
| #6936(warm cache) | 150 - 200 | 10%-30% | 130 - 170 |
| #6918(faster sigcache) #6914(prevector) | 130 - 150 | 20%-30% | 100 - 120 |

These numbers should be taken to be rough estimates.  They were collected from a series of different tests.  I reran different binaries over a historical simulation of all the p2p traffic for the month of October.  I also ran live binaries running the various PRs for the first 8 days of November.  I ran versions both with and without periodically calling CreateNewBlock to time it.  All of these PR's interact with each other significantly.  So running them in different combinations or with different arguments may lead to significantly different results.  I used the following settings:
- maxmempool=300
- dbcache=1000
- minrelaytxfee=0.0001
- maxsigcachesize=1000000  (or 80 for binaries including #6918)

events.body: Untested, code review ACK. Needs a unit test, though.
Together with #5967 it should be possible to also avoid the db read that's still done for coinbase transactions.
ok fixed the mess with the random nValue.

issue.title: Alter assumptions in CCoinsViewCache::BatchWrite
issue.body:
Previously it would break if you flushed a parent cache while there was a child cache referring to it.  This change will allow the flushing of parent caches.

It also modifies the unit test to include flushing of intermediate caches.

issue.body:

issue.title: [Core] ModifyNewCoins saves database lookups
issue.body:
Adapted version of bitcoin/bitcoin#6932

> When processing a new transaction, in addition to spending the Coins of its txin's, it creates a new Coins for its outputs. The existing ModifyCoins function will first make sure this Coins does not already exist. It can not exist due to BIP 30, but because of that, the lookup can't be cached and always has to go to the database. Since we are creating the Coins to match the new tx anyway, there is no point in checking if it exists first anyway. However this should not be used for coinbase tx's in order to preserve the historical behavior of overwriting the two existing duplicate tx pairs.
>
> In conjunction with bitcoin/bitcoin#6931 this will help ConnectBlock be much more efficient with caching access to the database.

We remove the restriction on coinbases, and thus use always `ModifyNewCoins` instead of `ModifyCoins`, since duplicated coinbases are not possible on PIVX (ref. #1775). 
Accordingly, we remove the logic for checking the effects of duplicate coinbase txs in the unit test.

issue.title: Backport of bitcoin/bitcoin#10195
issue.body:
Backport of bitcoin/bitcoin#10195 (bitcoin/bitcoin@1088b02f0ccd7358d2b7076bb9e122d59d502d02)

Work tree so far (read bottom-up)

- merge #4980 
- merge #4979 
- cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@e484652fc
  - requires bitcoin/bitcoin#9260 or patch to main.cpp
    - 0001-Introduce-CHashVerifier-to-hash-read-data.patch
- cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@f54580e7e
  - requires bitcoin/bitcoin#9260 or patch to main.cpp
    - 0001-error-in-disconnect-for-disk-corruption-not-inconsis.patch
      - cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@b50cd7a67e from bitcoin/bitcoin#9107
        - cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@07df40babb for coins_tests.cpp from bitcoin/bitcoin#9308
           - removed coinbase-specific sections
        - bitcoin/bitcoin@8504867b14: IGNORED, part of bitcoin/bitcoin#7056 that is not relevant to us
        - requires bitcoin/bitcoin@14470f9aa6 from bitcoin/bitcoin#6932: MERGED already in 2018
        - bitcoin/bitcoin#6931: IGNORED
          - No need for bitcoin/bitcoin@06d81ad516 but noted that we can 
            remove the "tried to overwrite transaction" check.
          - bitcoin/bitcoin@33c90cf1972 IGNORED
        - cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@072e2f86444 from bitcoin/bitcoin#5967 
          - required zcash-specific changes
- cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@e66dbde6d14
  - requires bitcoin/bitcoin#9346 
    - cherry-pick bitcoin/bitcoin@ed58969

comments.body:
If the purpose is to do this every 100 iterations, why use random?
Either the comment or the code is wrong :)
It's copied from the test above that I wrote. It's intended to be random, so the comment is wrong :)

If this was in production code I'd prefer to use a RAII pointer type (such as boost::shared_ptr) inside stack instead of explicit delete, because of exception safety and memory leaks.
As it is just the tests, mehh.

I believe I originally tried using boost::unique_ptr, but you can't use
that inside stl containers.

Right - I think shared_ptr is the only boost pointer you can use inside containers.

Edit: with **c++11** unique_ptr it should be possible, though, I guess we can change it by then :)
